Ask HN: How do you avoid signing on with a bad manager?
text:
In considering positions, what can you do to land with a good boss and avoid terrible ones? Or at least increase your odds?

I ask because I've been burned a couple times with people who seemed great, including someone with a reputation for building culture, only to discover they were terrible to work for, and then you're in the wrong job. And from my conversations and answers to my questions, I was excited to work for these people.

I know we can't guard against people outright lying, but beyond that, if you can't find someone who's worked for them and will give you the unvarnished truth, what are other things people can do when considering working for someone?

Or is this ultimately just a risk one has to take?

Ask HN: Multi-node tabbed text note editor/organizer
text: On windows I can still use KeyNote NF for editing notes, but there has never been replacement. Even cherrytree is only for a single xml tree. I used Jreepad until it became to difficult with modern macOS, but it has the same single xml tree issue. Is there anything out there I have overlooked for macOS? If possible I'd like to use it on linux as well and then I can sync between my mac mini and desktop linux.

Ask HN: For one-way publishing websites, are JavaScript UI frameworks helpful?
text:
Say you're building a web SITE (not a web APPLICATION).

This is a site that simply publishes content. There's no elaborate functionality or interactivity, other than a few web forms. The use cases is "click a link, view a page, click another link, view another page, etc."

Can a full JavaScript UI framework like React or Svelte provide value here? Are they worth the trouble over simple server-side templating/rendering of HTML (SSR)? Why or why not?
